status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

worklogs.comment:
AlenkaF opened a new pull request #11900:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11900


   We would like to add a **Tutorial** on how to **add a simple feature to PyArrow** that would be a part of the (New) Contributor's Guide.
   
   For this reason I made up a feature called `tutorial_min_max` that I added to `compute.py` plus a unit test to `test_compute.py.` The steps of making this PR will be added to the guide content separately [ARROW-14602](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-14602.)
   
   cc @jorisvandenbossche @amol- @dragosmg 


--

kszucs commented on pull request #11900:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11900#issuecomment-988877711


   Tipically there are three kinds of patches go to pyarrow:
   
   1. Plain python change like this example which doesn't require rebuilding pyarrow.
   2. Cython change touching `.pxi`, `.pyx`, `.pxd` files which requires rebuilding pyarrow (e.g. fixing something or exposing new libarrow functionality)
   3. C++ change along with Cython change where we add new code to libarrow[_python] too where we need to rebuild the C++ libraries as well.


--

issuetype.description: A new feature of the product, which has yet to be developed.
issuetype.name: New Feature

fields.description:
To create a guide tutorial for a simple Python feature I will add a made-up function to `compute.py` in order to demonstrate the process of making a first contribution.

The function will call `min_max` and increase the interval for 1 in both directions. I would call the new function `tutorial_example`.
fields.summary: [Python] Add a "made-up" feature for the guide tutorial

comments.body: What do you think about this feature [~amol-]?
[~amol-] [~jorisvandenbossche] MinMaxOptions are not yet set in compute.py and I can’t find an issue for it. Is this for some reason or am I missing something?
Update: MinMaxOptions have been changed to ScalarAggregateOptions in https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/9758/files#diff-694a635f185cf0d22dd6eefd91acedb48ed0bf71b15fd591aa6e7c508ba4cb09
Issue resolved with https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11900 and the Tutorial being merged https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-14602.
